BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind a high avalanche danger will prevail. Natural dry avalanches are to be expected already in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1200 m.
As a consequence of wind from southerly directions, dangerous wind slabs will form in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects.
In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and from starting zones at higher altitudes large and, in isolated cases, very large dry avalanches are to be expected. Avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.
It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Over a wide area new snow is lying on a hard crust. The new snow will become increasingly prone to triggering.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
The meteorological conditions will cause a substantial rise in the danger of dry avalanches during the course of the night.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From starting zones at higher altitudes very large natural avalanches, capable of reaching the valleys, must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a gathering strong southeasterly wind, large wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2000 m. As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase during the night. Numerous large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are to be expected, also in all aspects on steep slopes. In avalanche paths that are already filled with snow they can to an increasing extent reach the valleys.
The avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the peak of avalanche activity will be reached from the second half of the night.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
70 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Sunday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow of Sunday is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects, in particular on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in avalanche danger as the precipitation becomes more intense. Danger level 4 (high) will be reached from early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 70 to 90 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects.
As a consequence of wind from southeasterly directions, easily released wind slabs will form in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation large and, in isolated cases, very large dry avalanches are to be expected.
Many starting zones have released the snow but not entirely. Including in starting zones in which avalanches have already been released natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way, must be expected.
It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In all altitude zones a very large amount of snow is lying. As a consequence of snowfall and the southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is weak. The new snow of the last few days remains prone to triggering in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation this applies especially.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. The older wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
As a consequence of new snow and southeasterly wind, further wind slabs will form. Above the tree line and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the avalanche situation is dangerous.
In particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation large dry avalanches are to be expected. They can occur naturally.
It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
In some places new snow is lying on a hard crust. The new snow will become increasingly prone to triggering.
Weak layers exist in the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase during the night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a gathering strong southeasterly wind, sometimes large wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2000 m. Medium-sized and large natural avalanches are possible, also in all aspects on steep slopes. In avalanche paths that are already filled with snow they can in isolated cases reach a long way.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the peak of avalanche activity will be reached from the second half of the night.

The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,.
The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience and great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
60 to 90 cm of snow will fall until Sunday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow of Sunday is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in some places in all aspects, in particular on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar.

A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche danger will increase during the day. Weakly bonded old snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
During the day: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. Avalanches can reach large size. These will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Careful route selection is recommended.
Gradual increase in danger of gliding avalanches and wet snow slides as a consequence of the precipitation, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. These can in isolated cases reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. The wind will be strong to storm force in some cases. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. The new snow of the last few days is lying on surface hoar in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche danger will increase during the day. Weakly bonded old snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
During the day: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. Avalanches can reach large size. These will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Careful route selection is recommended.
Gradual increase in danger of gliding avalanches and wet snow slides as a consequence of the precipitation, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. These can in isolated cases reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. The wind will be strong to storm force in some cases. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. The new snow of the last few days is lying on surface hoar in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase from the second half of the night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a freshening southeasterly wind, wind slabs will form from the second half of the night in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2000 m. Fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. They can be released by a single winter sport participant. The current avalanche situation calls for experience and restraint.

Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible as the snowfall becomes more intense, also in all aspects on steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow will fall until Sunday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in some places. Caution is to be exercised on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the precipitation becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind a high avalanche danger will prevail. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming over a wide area will become increasingly prone to triggering. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In all aspects large to very large avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur. Single snow sport participants can release avalanches very easily.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area intensive precipitation. As a consequence of new snow and wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form. In particular places where weaknesses exist in the old snowpack are especially precarious.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The avalanche danger will persist.
The weather will be cloudy over a wide area. Light precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the precipitation becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind a high avalanche danger will prevail. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming over a wide area will become increasingly prone to triggering. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In all aspects large to very large avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur. Single snow sport participants can release avalanches very easily.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area intensive precipitation. As a consequence of new snow and wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form. In particular places where weaknesses exist in the old snowpack are especially precarious.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The avalanche danger will persist.
The weather will be cloudy over a wide area. Light precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the snowfall slab avalanches are possible, even very large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above approximately 1500 m. The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to rapid softening of the old snowpack over a wide area especially at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the snowfall numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large ground avalanches are possible above approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form. Caution is to be exercised on steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in particular at elevated altitudes.
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above the tree line. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. In particular in regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 4 (high) and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is greater.
Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size. Great caution and restraint are required.
In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach quite a large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of the moderate to strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. They are very prone to triggering.
Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1200 m snow will fall on Sunday over a wide area. In some localities 40 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and on steep slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily in all aspects above the tree line. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. As a consequence of the rain, the likelihood of gliding avalanches and snow slides being released will increase on very steep slopes below approximately 1400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular slopes adjacent to ridgelines are especially precarious.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In addition the new snow-covered wind slabs must be taken into account. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area intensive precipitation. As a consequence of new snow and wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form. In particular places where weaknesses exist in the old snowpack are especially precarious.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The avalanche danger will persist.
The weather will be cloudy over a wide area. Light precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Weakly bonded old snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force southerly wind, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. These will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally, in all aspects above the tree line. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Careful route selection is recommended.
In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. These can in isolated cases reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind will be strong to storm force in some cases. 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. The new snow of the last few days is lying on surface hoar in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The soft wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. In many cases avalanches are medium-sized and can be released easily even by a single winter sport participant. On steep grassy slopes more moist snow slides are possible as a consequence of the precipitation. In very isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of the moderate to strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be in most cases moist. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual, then as the precipitation becomes heavier more, and in some cases even medium-sized, gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and snowfall the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force southerly wind, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. These will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally, in all aspects above the tree line. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

In addition a certain danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. These can in isolated cases reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind will be strong to storm force in some cases. 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The weather conditions will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The solar radiation will give rise from early morning to gradual softening of the snowpack. Little snow has fallen in some localities.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally at high altitudes. Avalanches are possible in isolated cases as before. In the relevant regions these are mostly small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow of the last few days is lying on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack above approximately 1900 m. In the last few days small wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Some fresh snow and the wind slabs will be deposited on a quite favourable old snowpack above approximately 1700 m.
